channel.title: greenandlonely
channel.description: James Clarke's photo blog, with occasional words.

item.title: Hello!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I was a bit unhappy about being one of the only Web developers who didn't have an up-to-date website, so... tah-dah! Welcome, friend(s). Have a look around if you want, although I'm afraid you won't find much at the moment. Sorry for the lack of content right now but I'll slowly start adding new stuff and a few bells and whistles here and there, just as soon as I decide exactly what I want to do with the site.

item.title: We're going to Kenya!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: After several weeks and what seemed like tonnes of holiday brochures, we finally booked our holiday today. At the end of September, Steph and I fly to Kenya for two weeks! We're staying in a hotel on the coast for a couple of days, going on a 3 night safari in the Tsavo East & Tsavo West National Parks, then it's back to the hotel for the rest of the holiday. I think it's fair to say I haven't been this excited in years.

item.title: Warrenmusic
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I love playing the guitar, but most of the time I need all the help I can get when it comes to learning new songs. Tabs are quite good, although I sometimes find them quite difficult to follow. It doesn't help that most of the tabs I find are seldom correct. That's why I love this man. He films himself teaching near perfect renditions of Radiohead songs and posts the videos on YouTube for lazy/tab-illiterate people like me to learn. They're ideal for me because I pretty much only want to play Radiohead songs, and I'm always much better at learning something when it's demonstrated to me a couple of hundred times. I've recently been trying to tackle Jigsaw:

item.title: Focus, idiot
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
For the last few months I've found that, if left to my own devices, I haven't been able to concentrate on anything for long enough to actually get it done. No matter how much I want to achieve, within five minutes of starting I'll completely lose concentration and my mind will wander to other, much less important activities like checking email or watching crap on YouTube.
The worst thing is I don't exactly know why I do that, especially when there's so much I'd love to learn and experience. All I know is that my list of to-dos seems so long that to even arrange it into some sort of practical order is starting to look like a colossal task in itself. Of course, the longer I sit and moan about it, etc, etc.
Anyway, despite that, you might have noticed I've made a few additions to the site footer in the shape of a Twitter box and my Flickr photostream feed. Next up: styling and turning on comments. I'll be starting that next week, so expect it sometime in 2015.

item.title: OK to die now
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: My organ donor card has arrived in the post. I have no idea why I wasn't already a registered donor, I'd just never really thought about it before. Now I have been thinking about it, to me, organ donation seems to be something people should have to opt out of, rather than the other way round. If you feel the same, this is how to sign yourself up.

item.title: Yule blog
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I lost interest in this site quite a while ago, but I'm now back in a bit of a blogging mood so you can expect much more from me in 2011. This is mainly down to my deciding to embark on a 1-photo-a-day project type thing. I'll be posting all 365 photos here, so even if I don't write a lot, at least I'll be posting. Speaking of photos... I really wish I was a better photographer. I plan on getting better, which will involve reading interesting photography books (suggestions welcome) and hopefully buying a better camera (although with a move to Leamington Spa planned for some time in the next 18 months I can't really see that happening). Happy Jesus party!

It's just the sort of place I'd like to own in about 20 years. If I don't own a bookshop or cinema by then, that is. Note to self: go back again when it's open.

item.title: 18/365: "I wanna be able to see my face in it"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is the first daily photo taken with my new DSLR. I'd originally bought a second-hand Nikon D70s, but when it arrived broken and completely unusable I decided to return that and go for a brand new D3100. In short, it's ace, although I haven't worked out how to get the best out of it yet. For now at least, hopefully these photos will be slightly better quality.

By the way, if anyone wants to buy me a new lens or two I'll be your friend forever. Or a new bag. Anything, I'm not fussy.

item.title: greenandlonely 2.0
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I'd been threatening it for quite a while. So, during the Christmas break, with Nick Drake, Battles and Sigur Ros for company and Dr. Pepper for fuel, I finally re-designed the site.

I kind of just copied my favourite bits from a number of Wordpress sites and themes I'd seen, so if you think you recognise any parts of it, you're probably right.

Let me know what you think. It's not 100% done, but I decided that putting incomplete work live would act as the initiative I need in order to get it finished. That being said, I'm quite pleased it's got this far; the original design was only supposed to be there temporarily and it lasted for the best part of 2 years!

item.title: 57/365: A genuine original
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
On day 57 (Saturday to you) I went for a trip to the village of Tanworth-in-Arden to take some photos and visit the grave of - and what appears to be becoming a small shrine to - the excellent Nick Drake. Ever since I was introduced to his music the album Bryter Layter has been one of my favourites and it's truly sad that he died before getting the recognition he deserved.

The back of his gravestone features a couple of lines of his lyrics.

The sign for Tanworth-in-Arden post office.

item.title: 78/365: Sick!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Day 78 was a success, I'd say, and produced one of my favourites so far. This was taken just a short walk from my house at Reddicth Skate & BMX park. There were loads of people there, and I got so many almost great photos of them mid-jump (including a few of them upside down, mid-flip), but they were all moving so quickly that they weren't completely in frame.

Honorable mention goes to the photo below that would have possibly been my photo for this day, except for the fact that I found it on the camera about a week too late.

Some of the guys wanted to see what pictures I took and they reliably informed me that they're sick photos. That means they liked them.

I'm sure I'll be heading back there a couple more times before the project is up.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You're so old! These came out really well - did you use continuous focus and rapid shutter? Makes things so much easier with moving targets like this.

item.title: 105/365: Decisions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I've come to the realisation that I'm not great at judging whether my photos are good or not. This becomes difficult when I get more than one that I'm happy with and I don't know which one to choose for my 365 project. I probably always pick the wrong one.

The photos below are a good example. I chose the top one, but now I'm beginning to think that's the worst of the three.

Let me know which one you'd have chosen. Also, tell me if you even think any of them are actually any good. Positive or negative feedback is always welcome; I'll just be happy to get comments that aren't from spambots.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I think you made the right choice. It refelcts the energy of the situation. All of the photos I've seen have been awesome, especially the macro photography. If in future you feel you aren't qualified to choose then don't, show them all or let someone else choose for you. Don't doubt that you have the skill as a photographer to produce beautiful photos. Defiantly don't quit!

item.title: 114/365: Photowalk with Jasper
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Spent Sunday afternoon with Jasper on a photowalk around some of the less trodden parts of Birmingham. He knows loads about photography and it was great to talk about that stuff and get advice from him. He's also really good at spotting cool photo opportunities, which you'll notice if you read his blog. Which you should.

As is the norm when I post more than one, the top one is my photo of the day. I'm quite pleased with them all, but I chose that one because I think it'll look the best as a thumbnail next to the rest of them.

Have you subscribed to Jasper's RSS feed yet? Why the fuck not?

item.title: 115/365: Witley Court
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I was a little hung over, which is probably why I decided to take most of these from a seated or reclining position.

item.title: 116/365: Police tape
item.dc:creator: admin

item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: 119/365: Fly
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Got very lucky with this one; Steph and I were out for a quick walk and she just happened to notice it. I didn't have much time to think so I just took it and luckily it came out pretty well. Wish I could have got a bit closer but I was worried it would fly away.

Lemme know what you think...

item.title: 121/365: Puppy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
On Sunday we met Tilly, Steph's sister's new cavapoo puppy.

In case you hadn't noticed, she's a very sleepy dog. We were only there for about an hour and she fell asleep on 4 separate occasions. Not that I have anything to compare that to, for all I know that's normal for 9-week-old puppies.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Puppies only have two speeds really. When Sudo was tiny, it was like "zoom zoom zoom sleeeeep zoom zoom zoom sleeeeep" for like 3 or 4 months. These are adorable - submit them to dailypuppy.com

In other news, I've recently remembered how much I like Silent Alarm by Bloc Party. It's a bit too long, but when it's good, it's fantastic. Especially the drums.

item.title: Photos for Kulturplatz
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
After a request from a guy on a Radiohead forum, last week I took lots of pictures of the King of Limbs newspaper album for a short report he was producing for Swiss TV. The brief was to take photos of the individual elements (vinyl, CD, artwork and newspaper) from above. Nothing fancy... i.e. not slanted; no angles, I believe were his words.

Anyway, it has now been on TV and, if you want, you can watch it here. The photos are mostly near the start and near the end. I had to take them outside to take advantage of the evening light, so you'll notice our paving stones in some of the shots. I kind of assumed he'd crop those out, but what the hell.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
We decided against cropping because the paving stones give a more natural look :-)
Thanks again for your help!

item.title: 132/365: Digbeth
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I stopped in Digbeth on my way home from work on Thursday and spotted about 10 future photo opportunities, including this.

I'd originally planned on using another, better, photo for my 365 but I liked the light on this when I walked past, so this one it is. I can always go back and get my first choice again another day.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I'm quite pleased with this one; I like the light on the wheelchair. Mostly I like it because I was walking around Birmingham at lunch time, not getting any photos I liked, and I just happened to look in through a broken window of an abandoned building and spot it.

Although I'm sure I'm not, it's cool when it feels like I might be the only person who's noticed something.

This really nice man let me into his workshop and didn't mind me getting in the way and taking loads of pictures of him.

These were handheld, about 0.25 sec exposure. Any longer and I think he or I would have moved too much.

item.title: More Brighton
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
So yeah, as we expected, Brighton is ace. We spent most of our time there either shopping or eating. If you like good vegetarian food, Brighton's definitely the place to go.

I've decided to post slightly bigger photos from now on. I'm hoping they'll distract from the fact that I'm not writing anything interesting.

Love #4,5 and 6. Brighton is such a cool place to take photos - there's always something going on.

item.title: 162/365: Flyin' Ryan
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This is Flyin' Ryan, a motorcycle stunt man, at a show he was doing in Redditch. My Dad had lent me his telephoto lens, which turned out to be quite useful because they had set up safety barriers really far away from the ramp. It wasn't easy, partially because the lens is manual focus only, but I got these 2 that I was quite pleased with.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Taken at this week's Birmingham International Food Fair.

I didn't eat any of it. I had it when I was a kid and I remember it tasting awful, plus I'm not sure if it's vegetarian-friendly. Probably not.

item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: 169-171/365: Bulk
item.dc:creator: admin

I'm experimenting with bulk photo posting for a little bit. At least now there will be a reason behind the long hiatus between posts. Besides laziness, of course.

Properly wanted to give up on this project a few times this week.

item.title: 172/365: Blondie
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Really wish I could have got closer to this, but it was right in the corner of the door frame. Quite like the reflection, though.

item.title: 176/365: Fresh Air 2011
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Thanks to one of my Flickr contacts I was made aware of Fresh Air 2011, a sculpture exhibition held in a tiny village in the Cotswolds. I wasn't going to go, feeling disillusioned with my photos and all, but I'm glad I did in the end.

Today was mostly about reflections, it seems.

item.title: 178-182/365: Last week
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
After a few positive comments from people I went into last week with a bit more confidence about taking photos. Well, enough for me to actually enjoy doing it, which is way better than the last few weeks.

Took Steph and her sister to a concert at Villa Park on Tuesday. While I was driving around waiting for it to finish I spotted this through some gates:

It was a scrap yard, in which the shells of cars were stacked on top of one-another, with their engines and other parts scattered around nearby. I went back on Wednesday to get a shot and luckily somebody actually let me in, which is how I managed to get close enough to get the photo above. My confidence boost really paid off here; a few months ago there's no way I'd have had the guts to ask a (rather scary-looking) stranger to let me into his premises.

item.title: Old holiday snaps: Kenya
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Some photos from our trip to Kenya in Autumn 2009. Can't remember which ones were taken by me and which are Steph's, so I'll take credit for them all.

These were taken with our old Canon Powershot, probably on Auto mode, before I knew anything about cameras and stuff. Despite that, I'm quite pleased with some of the results.

I only like this bottom one because it looks like he's got arms.

item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: 177/365: Patience
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: It's a good job I had a free afternoon.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
When she wasn't ill, Steph spent a lot of last week cooking us lots of food. This meant I spent the week eating great food and spending more time on my 365 than I'm normally able to.

He was taking pictures of the paintings on the ceiling.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Good weekend, including a barbecue for two and a drive down to Bristol to see some family. Below is the flower of a leek that was growing in Steph's brother's garden.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This was taken at a talent show just down the road from the house. I quite like it, but I'm beginning to question the black & white.

And this one was in the car park of Touchwood Shopping Centre in Solihull. It looked quite cool on my Mac Mini and didn't need any editing, but seeing it on my Macbook makes me wish it wasn't so dark.

item.title: 192/365: .flies:hover
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I've been trying for over a week to get some pictures of these buggers. They recently turned up in our garden but they move so quickly it's been very hard to get anything decent. On Monday, though, I think I got the best I'm going to be able to, at least for now. I might try again some other time, but for now I'm fairly happy with these.

The ones below are some of my attempts from earlier in the week.

item.title: 201: John
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I've been thinking about doing a 100 Strangers project for a little while, as a way to get me more confident in both taking pictures of people and also approaching them to ask if I can do it in the first place.

John asking me for some spare change seemed like a good opportunity to start (he approached me after all), and in the end he was happy for me to take his picture.

item.dc:creator: admin

Any long weekend that begins with a funeral is going to suck, no matter how long it is.

Cat yawn.

item.title: 212: Leamington
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: We visited Leamington to have a walk around, look in a few estate agency windows, etc. We're really looking forward to moving there. Lots of saving to do in the meantime, though. Just got to keep reminding ourselves that the longer we wait, the more affordable it gets.

item.title: 213-215: Lunchtimes in the Jewellery Quarter

item.title: 218: We went to the zoo
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Day trips like this are exactly why I borrowed my Dad's telephoto lens. Sorry, Dad, I will give it back to you soon, I promise.

Dudley Zoo is quite nice. You should go.

The toilets.

The old chairlift.

If you think there are too many photos here, bear in mind I did take 500. This could have been so much worse.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Thanks, man, I really appreciate your comments.
If you want, let me know when you're next planning a trip up here & we can maybe arrange another photowalk.

Staff boarding up the furniture shop that got attacked last night.

These are a bit crap. Had to be quick though because the police were closing the roads.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I'm really enjoying taking photos at the moment. Not sure about some of the results, but I'm having fun trying. That's the important thing, right?

Had a few drinks and watched a Stewart Lee DVD on Friday night, then remembered I hadn't taken any photos.

item.title: 226: Coventry parkour
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
There's something I really love about walking around with a camera, trying to find stuff to take photos of. It can lead to some cool, spontaneous meetings with people I wouldn't have otherwise come across.

Tudor and Payam are two of the friendliest people I've met in a while and following them around Coventry was a good way to spend a Sunday afternoon. That town seems like the perfect place for parkour.

Kind of fucked up the processing of some of these - I'm using Fireworks for PC this week for a couple of stupid reasons, and I can't get it to do what I want most of the time. I took some other photos around Coventry that I might post a bit later, but definitely not until I'm back on Aperture.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thank you for this great photos. I'm looking forward to do some more :)

100 strangers, number 2.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Yeah, you're right, I think that's my main problem with those aswell. You put it a lot better than I could have too. Think I need to get you to ghost-write my posts from now on :)
Wow, you're building up a great set of camera kit. I'm looking forward to seeing the results.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I don't like doing it when they know I'm doing it. Even people who use cameras automatically strike a pose, which makes the whole thing feel really fake. S'why I'm hoping to invest in the 135mm in the next few weeks so I can get decent candids without people being aware. The 85's got some decent reach on it, but you still have to get kinda close.

wp:commentmeta.wp:meta_value: a:4:{s:4:"time";s:13:"1326723060.08";s:7:"message";s:55:"Akismet cleared this comment during an automatic retry.";s:5:"event";s:10:"cron-retry";s:4:"user";s:0:"";}

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Right place, right time. Heading into Birmingham I spotted him slowly walking up the street. Luckily I was able to turn down a side road and park, then run ahead of him and get this shot as I hid behind a phone box. Incredibly lucky, and the sort of thing that makes me want to always remember to take my camera everywhere I go.
Oh, and the first part of your comment made me choke on my Pepsi.

item.content:encoded: Probably my least favourite week of the project so far. I just didn't get the pictures I wanted, which, it appears, can knock my confidence and frustrate me.

item.title: 365: Didn't miscount, then
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I'm very pleased the project is over. As much fun as it was (and it really was, despite some moaning I may have done on here), in the last couple of months it sometimes felt less like fun and more like a chore. Still, I'm really glad I did it. I'm definitely going to keep taking photos and I'll probably continue to take my camera everywhere with me. I might even post some of the results on here, probably a lot less frequently than I did in 2011, though.

Anyway, below are some more photos I took on day 365.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Congratulations! I can empathise with the relief and the feeling that it was a chore, but you've captured some really excellent photos and it's a great way to learn the ins and outs of your camera. I pathologically take mine everywhere now, too.

item.title: London

item.content:encoded:
The results of a nice long photowalk with Jasper. Despite one of them not being in focus and another one looking like it was taken from a moving vehicle, I ended up liking these more than I thought I would.

I think he won, though, the git.
